Preparing the Implementation of Asian City 
Transport–Promoting Sustainable Urban Transport 
in Asia Project 
(Financed by the Climate Change Fund) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  This  regional  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA)  is  part  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank’s (ADB) Sustainable Transport Initiative (STI), which was created in 2006 to 
enhance ADB’s transport sector interventions by incorporating energy efficiency and inclusive 
transport  infrastructure  and  services  with  the  explicit  aim  to  reduce  transport  sector  GHG 
emissions.1 Previous STI activities have examined sustainable urban transport (SUT) in five 
pilot  cities  (Harbin  and  Changzhou,  People’s  Republic  of  China;  Dhaka,  Bangladesh; 
Kathmandu, Nepal; and Colombo, Sri Lanka)2 and a development framework for SUT.3 These 
activities’ findings were disseminated during the September 2008 ADB Transport Forum,4 which 
generated  significant  interest  from  developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  toward  exploring 
mainstreaming environmentally SUT interventions into ADB’s lending programs. 
 
2.  Therefore, this PPTA proposes to develop SUT programs and projects in selected DMC 
cities by implementing the findings of previous STI work.5 The cities will provide demonstration 
cases for low carbon urban transport solutions and act as a catalyst for further SUT work in 
ADB’s lending portfolio. The PPTA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  DMCs’ transport sectors can propel poverty reduction by making economic activity, 
health care, education, and social development accessible and mobile. In its strategy for poverty 
reduction  and  enhanced  economic  development  across  the  region,  ADB  supports  the 
development impacts that transport provides, with the sector encompassing over 35% of ADB’s 
lending portfolio.  
4.  The sector is facing new challenges in rapidly developing Asian economies as outlined 
in  two  pillars  of  ADB’s  long-term  strategic  framework  2008–2020  (Strategy  2020): 6  (i) 
environmentally sustainable growth, and (ii) inclusive economic growth. These challenges are 
especially steep for SUT. Congestion often curtails the economic activities that cities provide to 
national economies,7 and rapid urbanization is leading to income disparities and restricting the 
ability of the urban poor to realize their full economic roles.  
 
5.  Trends in the urban transport sector have focused on increasing physical capacity to 
alleviate congestion, often allocating additional road space to private vehicles. The end result is 
increasingly congested and polluted cities, in which energy-efficient and inclusive nonmotorized 
and public transport—the main modes of travel for the urban poor—compete with private cars. It 
is estimated that around 20% of urban transport trips, which are made by private vehicles, 
receive around 80% of the sector’s investments. A new approach is needed to move goods and 
services through integrated land use, inclusive urban transport services, and restraints to private 
vehicle use.

6.  In addition, the traditional transport approach often ignores the environmental and health 
impacts from pollution and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. Over the past three decades, 
carbon dioxide emissions from transport have risen faster than those from other sectors, with 
the greatest increases seen in Asia’s cities. Projections of future urban transport emissions are 
not encouraging, and climate change impacts must now be considered an integral aspect of 
transport policy and projects, particularly urban transport. 
 
7.  ADB’s STI falls under the umbrella of its climate change program, highlighting the role of 
urban transport in climate change mitigation. The use of the Climate Change Fund for this PPTA 
shows ADB’s commitment to environmentally sustainable growth of its transport sector. 
 
8.  The new approach to SUT must include the development of policies and projects that 
promote energy-efficient and inclusive urban transport modes. Three components are needed to 
move  people  and  goods  with  the  minimum  amount  of  energy  use  and  thus  reduce  GHG 
emissions: (i) integrated land use and mobility, reducing the need for travel and shipment of 
goods by locating places of employment, housing, and other services in livable and readily 
accessible communities; (ii) energy-efficient modes of urban transport, such as nonmotorized 
transport, public transport, or rail-based freight, to maximize energy use and to restrain private 
vehicle use for routine trips; and (iii) improve standards of vehicle and fuel technologies through 
policy dialogue. 
 
9.  Inclusive economic growth is also a core element of SUT, as increased congestion and 
travel times have a direct impact on travel costs. Moreover, urban expansion means that places 
of employment are often far away from residential areas, resulting in ever higher travel costs. As 
the urban poor often live on a city’s fringe where land or housing is cheaper, they are the most 
exposed to high travel costs.  
 
10.  Affordable and reliable urban transport services are required to allow the urban poor to 
access economic opportunities. Nonmotorized and public transport tend to be the travel modes 
of the poor; thus, the promotion of such modes over those of private vehicles will ensure that the 
urban poor are able to move around cities and engage in economic activities. 
 
11.  In addition, the poor are more exposed to the transport sector’s negative externalities, 
most notably accidents and pollution, and suffer the most from inefficient urban transport. Many 
activities of the poor are undertaken on the streets where pollution levels are higher and 
pedestrians are in danger of road accidents. An integrated approach to SUT must have the 
benefits of environmentally sustainable and inclusive economic growth, as well as mitigate the 
sector’s negative externalities, in order to aid the poor. 
 
12.  The challenge for Asian cities is to deliver a linked urban transport system, which will (i) 
increase investment in the existing mode share (public transport, nonmotorized transport, and 
pedestrian facilities, which account for around 70% of trips in most Asian cities); and (ii) arrest 
the rush toward private motorized transport. In addition, there should be zero implementation 
lags in adopting technical standards and specifications for vehicles and fuels.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The PPTA’s impact will be to decrease the rate of GHG emissions from DMCs’ transport 
sector. The outcome of the PPTA will provide demonstration cases of energy efficient urban

3
transport solutions that will lead to significant GHG emission reductions. Assistance will focus 
on transport programs and projects that ensure inclusive, energy-efficient, and clean energy 
transport systems, supported by ADB pipeline investments in sustainable transport in targeted 
DMCs. The PPTA will enable ADB to engage in policy dialogue with DMCs to develop SUT 
policies, addressing the negative externalities of climate change, fuel security, social costs of 
health and accidents, and accessibility for all. The PPTA will also serve as ADB’s focal point in 
developing ADB’s leading role among multilateral development banks for climate change in the 
transport sector. The PPTA will aim to assess relevant approaches, such as a sectoral clean 
development mechanism for transport, for any post-2012 climate regime and thus achieve the 
intended impact of the PPTA. 
 
14.  Further,  the  PPTA  will  aim  to  provide  for  the  increased  demand  for  urban  travel. 
Transport analysis and policy solutions will be developed in selected cities to address energy 
use and to decrease the sector’s climate change contributions through clean, low-carbon urban 
transport infrastructure and services. Inclusive urban transport systems will be prioritized to 
ensure pro-poor accessibility by focusing on modes predominately used by the urban poor, 
including nonmotorized and public transport. Replicable pilot interventions will be developed to 
ensure that future ADB urban transport sector interventions are inclusive and environmentally 
sustainable. 
 
15.  The PPTA will identify policy and projects in three selected DMCs cities; working closely 
with regional departments to demonstrate improved urban transport investments and services.  
Such work will be based on the findings of earlier STI technical assistance projects and promote 
personal mobility, pedestrian facilities, public transport improvements, equitable allocation of 
road space, integrated land use and transport facilities and restraints to private vehicle use. 
Work will be closely coordinated with other ADB initiatives under Strategy 2020 (footnote 6) and 
enhance ADB’s work in the urban sector. As such, close ties will be developed between this 
PPTA and the Cities Development Initiative for Asia.8  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
16.  To achieve the outcome of ADB’s STI and to align ADB’s transport sector with the 
delivery of clean and energy efficient transport infrastructure and services, a commitment and 
prioritization of SUT pipeline projects will be developed. The PPTA will provide demonstrational 
best practices in the selected cities. The lessons learned from the PPTA will be scaled up and 
scaled out to other cities across the region. A staff member within each relevant regional 
department will be designated as advocate for clean and energy efficient transport and SUT 
interventions.  
 
17.  To ensure a focus on the GHG emission reductions is achievable and to gain a full 
understanding of the transport sector contribution to climate change, the work will establish a 
baseline and future projections of transport GHG emissions in the selected cities. The work will 
provide a methodology and monitoring mechanism that will enable DMCs to monitor sector 
GHG emissions and to provide supporting documentation of policies or projects developed to 
mitigate such emissions. The mechanism will be implemented in selected DMCs as part of this 
PPTA to test its performance. A review of ADB projects will be undertaken to assess the climate

change  impacts  of  interventions,  thus  enabling  a  clearer  understanding  of  the  sector’s 
emissions and ADB’s role in mitigating these in future interventions. The PPTA will provide 
information to the parties at the Conference of Parties and other relevant meetings to ensure 
that pertinent information is available that highlights the sector’s GHG contributions and that 
they are accounted for in post-2012 agreements. 
 
18.  The cities selected for the PPTA are based on previous STI work and in consultation 
with the regional departments. Each of the selected cities show a high propensity to address 
SUT challenges in a comprehensive way that will reduce energy use, improve energy efficiency 
and  reduced  GHG  emissions.  The  proposed  cities,  Harbin,  PRC;  Kathmandu,  NEP;  and 
Vientiane, Lao People’s Democratic Republic provide a selection of city types and geographical 
distribution. A policy agreement between these cities and ADB will be pursued and will be 
signed  prior  to  allocation  of  PPTA  funds.  Policy  dialogues  with  the  selected  cities  will  be 
undertaken to determine the challenges and priorities, and from these, pilot SUT projects will be 
developed at a prefeasibility stage for inclusion in future country partnership strategies.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The total cost of the PPTA is estimated at $2,800,000. It will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Climate Change Fund. DMCs have been informed that approval of the PPTA does 
not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. The cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  ADB  will  be  the  executing  agency  for  the  PPTA.  The  Regional  and  Sustainable 
Development Department (RSDD) will oversee the overall administration of PPTA activities. All 
activities related to city policy development and identification of pipeline projects for possible 
ADB financing will be undertaken in coordination with the regional departments. For example, 
the regional departments and RSDD will collaborate in drawing up a work plan for selected 
DMC cities and estimating the resources and consulting services needed to undertake the 
planned activities. The regional departments will then oversee the consultants’ performance and 
technical  outputs.  RSDD  will  play  a  supportive  administrative  and  technical  role,  including 
administering the contracts of the consultants and compiling the outputs of the various contracts 
into a cohesive set of policies, action plans, and project preparations. The Transport Community 
of Practice will play an active role in moving the STI agenda forward. Project development 
activities funded by this PPTA will only begin in a particular DMC after ADB has received written 
confirmation from the DMC government that it has no objection to its inclusion in the PPTA.  
 
21.  The PPTA will begin in February 2009 and conclude in December 2010 (23 months). It 
will  require  an  estimated  57  person-months  of  international  consulting  services  and  94  
person-months of national consulting services. The engagement of consultants will be phased 
according to the sequence of activities. The international consultants will be expected to spend 
most of their time in the field. The detailed terms of reference will be drafted in consultation with 
the regional departments for each work component. Most international consultants are expected 
to  be  recruited  as  individuals  because  of  the  need  to  source  specialized,  country-specific 
expertise.  Individual  consultants  will  be  engaged  through  either  time-based  or  lump-sum 
contracts. If a firm must be recruited for complex jobs involving multiple types of expertise, the 
firms will be recruited using the quality- and  cost-based selection, quality-based selection, 
consultants’ qualifications selection, or single-source selection methods, depending on the value 
of the contract and the complexity of the assignment. Also, firms will submit either full or biodata

5
technical proposals, and be awarded either time-based or lump-sum contracts. The recruitment 
of  consultants  will  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference are in 
Appendix  3.  Disbursements  under  the  PPTA  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  the  ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (January 2008, as amended from time to time), 
and all procurement of goods and other services under the PPTA will be done in accordance 
with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). Upon completion of 
the PPTA, all equipment procured by the consultants under the PPTA will be turned over or 
disposed of in accordance with ADB’s Project Administration Instructions.9  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
 
22.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $2,800,000 on a grant basis for preparing the Implementation of 
Asian City Transport–Promoting Sustainable Urban Transport in Asia Project.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  This regional project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) activity—preparing the 
Implementation of Asian City Transport–Promoting Sustainable Urban Transport in Asia—will 
take place over 23 months beginning February 2009. The PPTA will require about 57 person-
months of international consulting and about 94 person-months of national consulting. The 
international consultants will have expertise in (i) transport and climate change emissions, (ii) 
evaluation  of  transport  projects  for  climate  change  aspects,  (iii)  a  clean  development 
mechanism (CDM) or similar mechanism applicable to the transport sector, (iv) sustainable 
urban  transport  (SUT),  and  (v)  multicriteria  analysis  of  transport  projects.  The  national 
consultants will have expertise similar to, and will coordinate their work with, the international 
consultants.  
 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  Transport and Climate Change Emissions Experts–Activities 2.1 and 2.2 
(various international consultants, up to 4 person-months, total) 
 
2.  The consultants will provide inputs to demonstrate the role transport plays in climate 
change, focusing on SUT. Their work will be used to demonstrate the baseline and projected 
transport emissions as background information to support the discussion on ensuring transport 
is  incorporated  into  any  post-2012  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  agreements  and 
mechanisms.  
 
3.  The consultants will undertake the following:  
 
(i)  report to the Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD) project 
specialist on the work outputs; 
(ii)  review existing information, data sources, and reports on transport sector climate 
change  emissions,  and  collate  the  various  information  to  provide  a 
comprehensive assessment of baseline and projected levels of emissions in the 
region; 
(iii)  in  selected  developing  member  countries  (DMCs),  develop  a  baseline  and 
monitoring mechanism to evaluate the transport sectors’ greenhouse gas (GHG) 
emissions,  and  outline  the  requirements  for  such  a  mechanism  to  be 
implemented; 
(iv)  assist in discussions with DMCs regarding developing and implementing such 
monitoring mechanisms; 
(v)  as required, participate in official missions to DMCs on issues related to baseline 
emissions data and monitoring mechanisms; and 
(vi)  prepare a report summarizing the respective outputs of the work. 
 
4.  The consultants should have at least 5 years of experience in transport and climate 
change emissions work. Master’s degrees in environment, engineering, economics, or related 
fields are preferred. 
 
2.  Transport Project Evaluation Specialists–Activity 2.3  
(various international consultants, up to 4 person-months, total) 
 
5.  The  consultants  will  review  selected  ADB  transport  sector  projects  to  assess  their 
climate change impacts. This review will include assessment of the level of climate change

impacts  considered  during  the  projects’  development  stages,  review  of  alternate  analyses 
undertaken with respect to climate change impacts, and development of their climate change 
“footprints”. 
 
6.  The consultants will undertake the following:  
 
(i)  report to the RSDD project specialist on the work outputs; 
(ii)  review selected ADB projects for project development and inclusion of climate 
change impacts, if applicable; 
(iii)  develop a mechanism to monitor the climate change impacts of projects than can 
be replicated and used for all transport sector projects undertaken by ADB; 
(iv)  review specific projects to estimate their climate change “footprints”; and 
(v)  prepare a report summarizing the respective outputs of the work. 
 
7.  The consultants should have at least 10 years of experience in transport evaluation and 
climate change emissions work. Master’s degrees in environment, engineering, economics, or 
related fields are preferred. 
 
3.  Kyoto Protocol Transport Experts–Activities 2.4  
(various international consultants, up to 5 person-months, total) 
 
8.  The consultants will assess the current CDM and other mechanisms, outlining in each 
case their relevance to the transport sector. The work will include an assessment of projects 
approved or under consideration, including those that have been submitted but not approved, to 
understand how the mechanism accounts for emissions from the transport sector. With an 
understanding of how post-2012 mechanisms are likely to be developed, the consultants will 
provide detailed methods that account for transport sector-type projects and policies, including, 
but not necessarily limited to, sectoral or project-based approaches.  
 
9.  The consultants will undertake the following:  
 
(i)  report to the RSDD project specialist on the work outputs; 
(ii)  review  transport  sector  projects  submitted  and  critique  the  processes, 
highlighting  areas  of  concern  for  transport  sectors’  inclusion  in  current 
mechanisms; 
(iii)  using climate change and transport sector work developed as part of this PPTA, 
assess how future levels of climate change emissions can be accounted for in 
post-2012 agreements; 
(iv)  define detailed mechanisms that are applicable and relevant to the transport 
sector and the evolving post-2012 mechanism; 
(v)  provide briefing materials, as required, to ADB and negotiators that support the 
position of transport in post-2012 mechanisms; 
(vi)  as required, participate in official missions to DMCs or workshops to support the 
inclusion of transport in post-2012 mechanisms and agreements; and 
(vii)  prepare a report summarizing the respective outputs of the work. 
 
10.  The consultants should have at least 10 years of experience in transport or climate 
change work and possess demonstrated experience in CDM or a related mechanism process. 
Master’s degrees in engineering, economics, environment, or related fields are preferred.

12  Appendix 3 
4.  Sustainable Urban Transport Specialists–Activities 3.2 and 3.3  
(various international consultants, up to 8 person-months per selected city) 
 
11.  The consultants will provide a strategic overview of selected cities’ transport systems 
and their challenges, and outline, at a strategic level, the basis of an SUT program. Project 
identification will be carried out, initially at a strategic level, for those that will demonstrate 
adherence to clean, inclusive, and SUT provisions. Details of an SUT policy will be developed 
and presented for each of the selected cities. The consultants will assist in the policy dialogue in 
the selected cities regarding the development of SUT policy, programs, and projects.  
 
12.  The  consultants  should  have  at  least  10  years  of  experience  in  the  various  team 
positions, with at least 5 years of which were dedicated to SUT. Previous working experience in 
the  region,  particularly  within  ADB’s  DMCs,  is  required.  Master’s  degrees  in  engineering, 
economics, management, or related fields are preferred. 
 
13.  Once agreement is reached on policy direction for the selected cities, a consultant team 
will develop policy and project preparation work to a prefeasibility level for prioritized clean and 
inclusive SUT projects, which will vary by city relating to the findings and priorities identified in 
the strategic-level review and policy dialogue. The team is likely to consist of the following 
consultants: (i) transport planner, (ii) policy specialist, (iii) transport economist, (iv) institutional 
specialist, (v) financial expert, (vi) climate change expert, (vii) social development specialist, and 
(viii) urban development specialist. 
 
5.  Transport Multicriteria Analysis Experts–Activities 3.4, 3.5 and 3.6  
(various international consultants, up to 11 person-months, total) 
 
14.  The consultants will review current best practices in urban transport project evaluation, 
particularly multicriteria analysis approaches. A framework will be developed that allows the 
evaluation and use of a multicriteria analysis approach for urban transport project evaluation in 
selected DMC cities. The work should include all transport impacts, both positive and negative, 
and include traditional transport variables such as congestion, time savings, and accidents in 
addition to climate change, local pollution, social issues, and inclusive development. 
 
15.  The consultants will undertake the following:  
 
(i)  report to the RSDD project specialist on the projects’ work; 
(ii)  review current best practices in urban transport project evaluation, and make 
suggestions as to their relevance in a DMC context; 
(iii)  develop a mechanism for full cost-benefit analysis of SUT sector interventions 
and policy programs using multicriteria analysis methodologies; 
(iv)  evaluate co-benefits of energy efficient and inclusive transport projects, including 
energy  security,  climate  change,  local  pollution,  congestion,  travel  times, 
operating and transport costs, safety, and social inclusiveness; 
(v)  develop a monitoring mechanism for pro-poor, SUT impacts of ADB interventions 
and DMC transport infrastructure and service development;  
(vi)  pilot the methodology in selected DMC cities;  
(vii)  as required, participate in official missions to DMCs on issues related to baseline 
emissions data and monitoring mechanisms; and 
(viii)  prepare a report summarizing the respective outputs of the work.

Appendix 3  13 
16.  The  consultants  should  have  at  least  10  years  of  experience  in  transport  project 
evaluation, at least 5 years of which were dedicated to urban transport; and previous working 
experience  in  the  region,  particularly  within  ADB’s  DMCs.  The  consultants  must  have 
demonstrated  experience  in  innovative  and  holistic  project  evaluation.  Master’s  degrees  in 
engineering, economics, management, or related fields are preferred. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
1.  Transport and Climate Change Emissions Specialists–Activity 2  
(up to 18 person-months) 
 
17.  The consultants will provide technical support to RSDD in data collection and collation, 
the development of the monitoring framework activities, and review of ADB transport sector 
projects covered under activity 2. The national consultants will work alongside the international 
consultants and will be engaged intermittently during implementation. 
 
18.  The national consultants should have at least 5 years of experience in transport, climate 
change, and project evaluation, at least 3 years of which were dedicated to urban transport.  
 
2.  Sustainable Urban Transport Specialists–Activity 3  
(up to 16 person-months per city) 
 
19.  The consultants will provide technical support to the regional departments and RSDD in 
all  selected  city  SUT  activities.  They  will  provide  technical  expertise  to  identify  clean  and 
inclusive urban transport in their respective countries, lead all market research and technology 
reviews in their countries, and participate in all local coordination meetings and reviews of 
progress of work. They will be engaged intermittently during implementation. 
 
20.  The consultants should have at least 5 years of experience in transport projects, at least  
3 years of which were dedicated to urban transport. They must have demonstrated experience 
in public transport land use planning in their own DMCs and in the design and monitoring of 
transport projects.
